The VCU Health System supports the university's health care education, research and patient care mission.)

Virginia Commonwealth University traces its origins to **1948** with the establishment of the Medical College of Virginia (MCV) as a branch of the University of Virginia. Initially focused on medical and health sciences education, MCV rapidly expanded its offerings and facilities throughout the mid-20th century. The subsequent merger with the Richmond Professional Institute (RPI) in 1968 marked a pivotal moment, creating the modern Virginia Commonwealth University. This consolidation brought together diverse academic disciplines, transforming the institution into a comprehensive public university with a broad range of undergraduate and graduate programs, significantly broadening its scope and impact beyond its initial medical roots. The early decades were characterized by growth, innovation in healthcare education, and a commitment to serving the Commonwealth of Virginia.

The university is a member school of the Thurgood Marshall College Fund.)

The opening track on the 1991 compilation box set *Back to Mono (1958–1969)* is the iconic "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)". This soulful lament, penned by the prolific songwriting duo Jeff Barry and Ellie Greenwich, captures the profound yearning for a loved one's return during the holiday season. The song's lyrics express a deep sense of loneliness and longing, juxtaposing the festive atmosphere with the pain of separation. Barry's collaborative efforts in crafting this enduring holiday classic cemented its place as a staple of Christmas music, resonating with listeners through its raw emotion and heartfelt plea. The themes of absence, hope, and the desire for reunion are powerfully conveyed, making "Christmas (Baby Please Come Home)" a poignant and unforgettable opener for the comprehensive *Back to Mono* collection.
Doc 2(Title: "Back to Mono (1958–1969)" Back to Mono (1958–1969) is a box set (4 compact discs or 5 vinyl LPs) compilation of the recorded work of record producer Phil Spector, through the 1960s, released in 1991 by ABKCO as #7118-2. The first track, "To Know Him Is to Love Him," released in 1958, features Spector performing as part of the group the Teddy Bears. Initially a vinyl album-sized package, the box contained a booklet with photographs, complete song lyrics, discographical information, and a reproduction of the essay on Spector by Tom Wolfe, "The First Tycoon of Teen." The package also contained a small, round, red "Back to Mono" pin.) 
Doc 3(Title: "Mono Masters" Mono Masters is a compilation album by the Beatles, and is an alternate, all-mono version of the album "Past Masters". "Mono Masters" was originally a two-CD set included as part of "The Beatles in Mono" box set. The premise of this box set was to compile only Beatles material which was released or prepared for release with a dedicated mono mix (the set excludes later material mixed and released only in stereo, and material whose mono version was simply created as an equal mix of the two channels of the stereo version). Tracks 9–12 and 15 were prepared in March 1969 for release as a 7" mono "Yellow Submarine" EP, two months after the release of the similarly titled soundtrack album, but the project was scrapped, although the EP was mastered. Subsequently, the tracks were only released in stereo (and in an electronically produced mono mixdown, or "fold-down", of the stereo mix), while the true mono mixes remained unreleased. "Get Back" (with B-side "Don't Let Me Down") was the final Beatles single mixed for mono format. It was released in the UK in mono, though the US release was in stereo. Thus, the songs that were originally released on stereo singles in the UK are omitted on this release.)

<information>Doc 1(Title: "Who was the French flying ace and adventurer who piloted L'Oiseau Blanc? When and where did L'Oiseau Blanc attempt its transatlantic flight?") The pioneering transatlantic flight attempt of L'Oiseau Blanc, a French biplane, was made on May 8, 1927, from Le Bourget Airport in Paris, France, with the ambitious destination of New York City. While the aircraft and its pilots, Charles Nungesser and François Coli, tragically disappeared en route, their attempt was a significant precursor to later successful crossings. This daring endeavor aimed to capture the $25,000 Orteig Prize, a significant reward offered for the first non-stop flight between New York and Paris. The disappearance of L'Oiseau Blanc, just weeks before Charles Lindbergh's successful solo flight, added a poignant chapter to aviation history, fueling speculation and a deep sense of loss within the aviation community and the public alike. Despite its ultimate failure, the spirit of L'Oiseau Blanc and the bravery of its crew continued to inspire subsequent aviators pushing the boundaries of long-distance flight.
Doc 2(Title: "L'Oiseau Blanc" L'Oiseau Blanc (commonly known in the English-speaking world as The White Bird ) was a French Levasseur PL.8 biplane that disappeared in 1927, during an attempt to make the first non-stop transatlantic flight between Paris and New York City to compete for the Orteig Prize. The aircraft was flown by French World War I aviation heroes, Charles Nungesser and François Coli. The aircraft took off from Paris on 8 May 1927 and was last seen over Ireland. Less than two weeks later, Charles Lindbergh successfully made the New York–Paris journey and claimed the prize, flying the "Spirit of St. Louis".) 
Doc 3(Title: "Who was the French flying ace and adventurer who piloted L'Oiseau Blanc? What is the pilot's biography and other notable adventures or achievements?") Charles Lindbergh (1902–1974) was a pioneering American aviator, inventor, and author whose most celebrated achievement was the first solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic Ocean in May 1927. Piloting the *Spirit of St. Louis*, Lindbergh departed from Roosevelt Field, New York, and landed at Le Bourget Field in Paris, France, a journey of over 33 hours. This daring feat instantly made him a global hero and a symbol of human ingenuity and courage, earning him the nickname "Lucky Lindy." Beyond this iconic flight, Lindbergh's life was marked by a series of notable adventures and achievements. He was instrumental in developing instruments for aviation, including a blind-flying system that significantly improved air navigation safety. During World War II, Lindbergh, despite his earlier isolationist views, contributed to the war effort by working as a civilian consultant for aircraft manufacturers and by flying combat missions in the Pacific. His autobiography, *The Spirit of St. Louis*, won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1954, further cementing his legacy as a multifaceted historical figure.
</information>

<information>Doc 1(Title: "Which Australian city, established in 1838, is home to a boarding school that was opened by an Australian Prime Minister and shares its name with a London school? What is the history of the city founded in 1838 and what other notable institutions does it have?") Hobart, Tasmania, officially founded in 1838, boasts a rich colonial history as the second oldest Australian capital city. Established as a penal colony, it soon transitioned into a significant port and administrative centre for Van Diemen's Land. Its distinctive Georgian architecture, particularly in the Salamanca Place precinct, offers a tangible link to this early period. Beyond its historical significance, Hobart is home to several notable institutions that contribute to its cultural and scientific landscape. These include the University of Tasmania, a prominent centre for research and education, and the Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery, which houses extensive collections on the island's natural and cultural heritage. The city also serves as a vital gateway to Antarctica, with the Australian Antarctic Division based here, supporting scientific expeditions and research in the Southern Ocean.
Doc 2(Title: "Which Australian city, established in 1838, is home to a boarding school that was opened by an Australian Prime Minister and shares its name with a London school? What is the name of the boarding school and which Prime Minister opened it?") Opened in 1904, the **Hobart, Tasmania** Girls' School was established by Prime Minister Alfred Deakin. This institution was a significant development in Tasmanian education, providing opportunities for young women in the burgeoning colony. The school's inception reflected a broader national push towards improved secondary education and the empowerment of women in public life, with Prime Minister Deakin's attendance at the opening ceremony underscoring its national importance. The school has since undergone several transformations, adapting to evolving educational philosophies and societal needs.
Doc 3(Title: "Which Australian city, established in 1838, is home to a boarding school that was opened by an Australian Prime Minister and shares its name with a London school? Which London school is the Australian school named after, and what is its history?") The Australian school, specifically The King's School, Parramatta, NSW, is not named after a London school. Rather, it draws its name from the historic city of Hobart, Tasmania, which was itself named in honour of Lord Hobart, the then-Secretary of State for War and the Colonies, whose tenure included significant colonial administrative responsibilities. The King's School, founded in 1831 by Governor Sir Ralph Darling, was established as a grammar school for the colony, intended to provide an Anglican education similar to that offered by the prestigious King's School, Canterbury, in England. However, its direct titular connection is to the prominent Tasmanian settlement, reflecting the geographical and administrative realities of the British Empire at the time, rather than a direct appellation from a specific London institution. The school's history is deeply intertwined with the development of colonial education in Australia, aiming to instill British values and traditions within the burgeoning Australian society.
</information>
